results.title: The Blinds and the Shutters
results.brief_description: This work presents a virtual world comprised of a modernist fictional house in a remote forest setting, whose contents gradually spill and float out of every aperture. Shoes and dresses, pots and pans, cutlery, pillows, blankets and plates journey in two directions simultaneously, some disappearing into the distance never to return, others appearing across all four screens in the installation. The larger objects fade up like apparitions, disappear and then reappear in strange locations, breaking all logic that is guiding this imaginary world. The slow drift of these household objects around the four screens is uncanny. While their journey suggests that the natural phenomenon of air is present, there is also a sense of airlessness; a claustrophobic, almost heavily scented environment. Despite sharing an energy force within the virtual environment, these objects are estranged – for they have lost their domestic relationship with one another. The sounds of bumps, collisions and muffled shuffles emerging from the interior of the house underscores the mystery of this scene. The disturbing atmosphere is most bizarre when the household goods are propelled into outer space, taking on the form of miniature satellites presumably tracking our behaviour from afar.

results.title: Marco Solo
results.creator_credit: Adrian Bosich and VCA Film and Television School, University of Melbourne
results.brief_description:
Poor Marco. Accidentally born into an overcrowded Australian-Italian household, he is relegated to his parents’ bedroom. Nine years later, armed with a vivid imagination, an obsession with Dame Edna, and a warped sense of Catholicism, Marco searches for a space of his own. Cast includes Joseph Sollena, Robert Urban, Helen Nicholas, Irini Pappas, Maria Diele.
‘Marco Solo’ screened at many film festivals, including Palm Springs and London International Film Festival.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrian Bosich and VCA Film and Television School, University of Melbourne

results.title: Blue Tongue
results.creator_credit: Justin Kurzel, Timothy Jolley and VCA Film and Television School, University of Melbourne
results.brief_description:
On the fringes of a housing estate a girl seduces a boy with a secret she will only reveal in exchange for his love. When the boy fails to honour the pact, what he holds close is threatened by the girl’s desire for revenge. Cast: Arlan Fahey Leigh and Siana Smit.
In 2005 ‘Blue Tongue’ was the first Australian short film to be selected for screening at the International Critics Week at the Cannes International Film Festival.

results.title: Women of the iron frontier
results.creator_credit: Fraser Film and Video, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Lilias Fraser
results.brief_description: Filmed in the remote Pilbara region in far north Western Australia this is a moving revelation of the struggle of women who are trying to create a life for themselves in the hostile environment of outback iron ore mining towns. “Time goes very slowly” deals with the problems of isolation and unemployment for women in Newman. “It’s not a community anymore” tells of the ongoing effects of the bitter 1986 Robe River industrial dispute upon families in the town of Wickham. “It’s supposed to be a town” explores racism through the eyes of both the black and white women of Newman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Fraser Film and Video, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Lilias Fraser

results.title: What Do We Want?
results.creator_credit: Molly O'Connor, Philippa Campey, Film Camp and Reko Rennie
results.credit_line:
2022
Reko Rennie, Kamilaroi
Three-channel video
Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
results.brief_description: What Do We Want will draw on 1970s Blaxploitation films and Rennie’s own martial arts practice to explore political, environmental and social questions through an Aboriginal Australian lens.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Molly O’Connor, Philippa Campey, Film Camp and Reko Rennie
results.description:
An army of First Nations warriors come out to play in this latest action-packed video by Kamilaroi artist Reko Rennie.

An all-Indigenous crew of martial arts students train together in their dojo; learning teachings of discipline, self-defense and teamwork. When the Sensei cries, “What do we want?” the students respond, “Restitution! Land back! Equality! No more cops killing our mob!”, vocalising demands of environmental, political and social concern, and reflecting the broad diversity within contemporary Indigenous urban society.

Rennie was taught martial arts by his father while growing up in Melbourne’s inner West. What Do We Want? marries his 25-year history of martial arts and his arts practice, while expanding Rennie’s evolving moving image repertoire into the realm of performance.

What Do We Want? takes influence from martial arts films including Blaxploitation films of the 1970s and 80s; utilising the medium to make a statement about authenticity, respect, bravery and collective power. The students in What Do We Want? become a force to be reckoned with.

Displayed in the gallery in a massive three-channel video installation, the work loudly and proudly conveys the diversity of First Nations peoples, and the ongoing fight for justice that unifies them, raising urgent questions that require action and response.

Acknowledgements

Director: Reko Rennie

Produced by Film Camp, Philippa Campey, Molly O’Connor

Original composition by A.B. Original

Produced by Trials

Director of Photography: Sherwin Akbarzadeh

results.title: Kiewa catchment farm tree group: a community in action
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Rural Affairs. North Central Media Unit, John Atkins and Ian Blythman
results.brief_description: The Kiewa community formed a tree planting group to combat the problems of land degradation due to the impact of agricultural practices, the effect of tourisism in the area and erosion. This video shows how a small community in the alpine area of north-east Victoria, worked together to deal with an environmental problem.

results.title: Horse breaking
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Agrifilm
results.brief_description: Depicts 72 year-old Kel Jeffrey applying his unique and humane method of gaining a horse’s confidence to the point where it will allow a saddle to be placed on its back and a person to ride it.
results.description: Depicts 72 year-old Kel Jeffrey applying his unique and humane method of gaining a horse’s confidence to the point where it will allow a saddle to be placed on its back and a person to ride it.

results.title: The Rabies threat
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Shows the problems caused by the animal disease rabies, and outlines the work of the Animal Quarantine Service which functions to keep out of Australia all exotic animal diseases.
